--- pagetitle: Binomial Trend Detection description: | Explore a robust method for trend detection using binomial analysis, focusing on week-over-week comparisons to identify significant patterns in data. execute: freeze: auto --- ::: column-page # Binomial Trend Detection ::: ::::: column-screen :::: portfolio-banner ::: column-page One common approach to highlighting trends and detecting anomalies is **rolling average benchmarking**. This method involves comparing each new data point to the average of a specified number of preceding values. By smoothing out short-term fluctuations, it becomes easier to identify deviations that may indicate a potential trend shift or anomaly.
However, this method has some limitations. It is sensitive to the chosen window size, can introduce lag, and may struggle to account for seasonality or sudden changes in the data. ::: :::: ::::: ::: {.column-page .binom} An alternative method to detect trends more robustly is a **binomial trend detection approach**, which uses a week-over-week (WoW) comparison. This is how the method can be implemented: | **Step** | **Details** | |----|----| | **Calculate WoW Deltas** | Compute the week-over-week changes (deltas) for the metric of interest. This involves determining whether the metric has increased or decreased each day. | | **Rolling 2-Week Window** | For each day, consider the previous 14-day period (2 weeks) as a rolling timeframe for analysis. This helps smooth out short-term variations while being responsive to recent changes. | | **Counting Positive and Negative Days** | Within the 14-day window, count the number of days where the WoW delta is positive and the number of days where it is negative. This provides insight into the recent performance pattern. | | **Binomial Distribution** | Assume that each day has an equal 50% chance of having either a positive or negative WoW delta. Under this assumption, the 14-day window is treated as 14 independent trials, each with a 50% probability of being positive or negative. | | **Trend Threshold** | Set a threshold to identify significant trends: for example, if 12 or more out of the 14 days show a consistent direction (either positive or negative), it is deemed statistically significant according to the binomial distribution. | ::: ::: {.cell .column-page} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} binom.test(12, 14, 1/2, alternative = "greater") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Exact binomial test data: 12 and 14 number of successes = 12, number of trials = 14, p-value = 0.00647 alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is greater than 0.5 95 percent confidence interval: 0.6146103 1.0000000 sample estimates: probability of success 0.8571429 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column-page .binom} This threshold helps ensure that the observed trend is not due to random fluctuations, but rather indicates a consistent pattern. ::: ::: {.cell .column-page} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/binom-visual-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.column-page .binom} This binomial approach balances longer rolling windows, reduces sensitivity to day-of-week variations, and adjusts to recent trends more effectively than simple rolling averages. :::
